questions.title: Hypothesis Testing
questions.question: An analyst suspects that, in the most recent year, excess returns on stocks have fallen below 5%. She wants to study whether the excess returns are less than 5%. Designating the population mean as Î¼, which hypotheses are most appropriate for her analysis?

choices.A: H 0 : Âµ = 5% versus H a : Âµ â‰  5%
choices.B: H 0 : Âµ > 5% versus H a : Âµ < 5%
choices.C: H 0 : Âµ < 5% versus H a : Âµ > 5%

questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. The null hypothesis is what she wants to reject in favor of the alternative, which is that population mean excess return is less than 5%. This is a one-sided (left-side) alternative hypothesis.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. The null hypothesis is what she wants to reject in favor of the alternative, which is that population mean excess return is less than 5%. This is a one-sided (left-side) alternative hypothesis.

questions.title: Hypothesis Testing
questions.question:
A Type I error is best described as the probability of:

  1. failing to reject a false null hypothesis.
  2. rejecting a true alternative hypothesis.
  3. rejecting a true null hypothesis.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. This is the definition of a Type II error. Incorrect. This is an entirely wrong statement and it is not one of possible outcomes when we test a null hypothesis. Correct . A Type I error is the mistake of rejecting the null hypothesis when it is, in fact, true. Hypothesis Testing explain hypothesis testing and its components, including statistical significance, Type I and Type II errors, and the power of a test.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect. This is the definition of a Type II error.

  2. Incorrect. This is an entirely wrong statement and it is not one of possible outcomes when we test a null hypothesis.

  3. Correct. A Type I error is the mistake of rejecting the null hypothesis when it is, in fact, true.

Hypothesis Testing

  • explain hypothesis testing and its components, including statistical significance, Type I and Type II errors, and the power of a test.

questions.title: Hypothesis Testing
questions.question:
Which of the following is most likely to be an explanation of the power of a test? The power of a test is the probability of:

  1. rejecting the null when it is false.
  2. not accepting the alternative when it is false.
  3. a Type I error.
questions.explanation: Solution Correct. The power of a test is the probability of correctly rejecting the nullâ€”that is, the probability of rejecting the null when it is false. Incorrect. The power of a test is the probability of correctly rejecting the nullâ€”that is, the probability of rejecting the null when it is false. If the alternative is not accepted when it is false, it means that a true null hypothesis is not rejected. Therefore, the probability of not accepting the alternative when it is false is not an explanation of the power of a test. Incorrect. The power of a test is the probability of correctly rejecting the nullâ€”that is, the probability of rejecting the null when it is false. The probability of a Type I error is equal to the probability of rejecting the null when it is true and is also known as the level of significance. Therefore, it is not an explanation of the power of a test. Hypothesis Testing explain hypothesis testing and its components, including statistical significance, Type I and Type II errors, and the power of a test.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Correct. The power of a test is the probability of correctly rejecting the nullâ€”that is, the probability of rejecting the null when it is false.

  2. Incorrect. The power of a test is the probability of correctly rejecting the nullâ€”that is, the probability of rejecting the null when it is false. If the alternative is not accepted when it is false, it means that a true null hypothesis is not rejected. Therefore, the probability of not accepting the alternative when it is false is not an explanation of the power of a test.

  3. Incorrect. The power of a test is the probability of correctly rejecting the nullâ€”that is, the probability of rejecting the null when it is false. The probability of a Type I error is equal to the probability of rejecting the null when it is true and is also known as the level of significance. Therefore, it is not an explanation of the power of a test.

Hypothesis Testing

  • explain hypothesis testing and its components, including statistical significance, Type I and Type II errors, and the power of a test.

questions.title: Hypothesis Testing
questions.question: Which of the following statements about hypothesis testing is correct?

choices.A: The null hypothesis is the condition a researcher hopes to support.
choices.B: The alternative hypothesis is the proposition considered true without conclusive evidence to the contrary.
choices.C: The alternative hypothesis exhausts all potential parameter values not accounted for by the null hypothesis.

questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. Together, the null and alternative hypotheses account for all possible values of the parameter. Any possible values of the parameter not covered by the null must be covered by the alternative hypothesis (e.g., H 0 : Î¼ â‰¤ 5 versus H a : Î¼ > 5). A is incorrect because the null hypothesis is what the researcher wants to reject; the â€œhoped forâ€ or â€œsuspectedâ€ condition is often set up as the alternative hypothesis. B is incorrect because the null (not the alternative) hypothesis is considered to be true unless the sample used to conduct the hypothesis test gives convincing evidence that the null hypothesis is false.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

C is correct. Together, the null and alternative hypotheses account for all possible values of the parameter. Any possible values of the parameter not covered by the null must be covered by the alternative hypothesis (e.g., H0: Î¼ â‰¤ 5 versus Ha: Î¼ > 5). A is incorrect because the null hypothesis is what the researcher wants to reject; the â€œhoped forâ€ or â€œsuspectedâ€ condition is often set up as the alternative hypothesis. B is incorrect because the null (not the alternative) hypothesis is considered to be true unless the sample used to conduct the hypothesis test gives convincing evidence that the null hypothesis is false.

questions.title: Hypothesis Testing
questions.question:
The probability of correctly rejecting a false null hypothesis is best described as one minus the:

  1. test statistic's p-value.
  2. probability of a Type I error.
  3. probability of a Type II error.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because the power of the test is equal to one minus the probability of Type II error. The p -value is a measure of Type I error and is synonymous with distracter B. Incorrect because the power of the test is equal to one minus the probability of Type II error. The p -value is a measure of Type I error and is synonymous with distracter B. Correct because the power of a test is the probability of correctly rejecting the nullâ€“that is, the probability of rejecting the null when it is false. Failing to reject the null hypothesis when it is false is a Type II error. So the power of the test is equal to one minus the probability of Type II error. Hypothesis Testing explain hypothesis testing and its components, including statistical significance, Type I and Type II errors, and the power of a test.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect because the power of the test is equal to one minus the probability of Type II error. The p-value is a measure of Type I error and is synonymous with distracter B.

  2. Incorrect because the power of the test is equal to one minus the probability of Type II error. The p-value is a measure of Type I error and is synonymous with distracter B.

  3. Correct because the power of a test is the probability of correctly rejecting the nullâ€“that is, the probability of rejecting the null when it is false. Failing to reject the null hypothesis when it is false is a Type II error. So the power of the test is equal to one minus the probability of Type II error.

Hypothesis Testing

  • explain hypothesis testing and its components, including statistical significance, Type I and Type II errors, and the power of a test.

questions.title: Hypothesis Testing
questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding the null hypothesis is correct?

choices.A: It can be stated as â€œnot equal toâ€ provided the alternative hypothesis is stated as â€œequal to.â€
choices.B: Along with the alternative hypothesis, it considers all possible values of the population parameter.
choices.C: In a two-tailed test, it is rejected when evidence supports equality between the hypothesized value and the population parameter.

questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. The null and alternative hypotheses are complements of one another and must be both mutually and collectively exhaustive. Differently put: all possible values or outcomes need to be contained in either the null or the alternative hypothesis. A is incorrect because the null hypothesis must always include the equality sign (less than or equal to, equal to, or greater than or equal to). C is incorrect because, in a two-tailed test, the null hypothesis is generally set up as equality between the hypothesized value and the population parameter. If evidence supports equality, then the null hypothesis would not be rejected.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. The null and alternative hypotheses are complements of one another and must be both mutually and collectively exhaustive. Differently put: all possible values or outcomes need to be contained in either the null or the alternative hypothesis.

A is incorrect because the null hypothesis must always include the equality sign (less than or equal to, equal to, or greater than or equal to). C is incorrect because, in a two-tailed test, the null hypothesis is generally set up as equality between the hypothesized value and the population parameter. If evidence supports equality, then the null hypothesis would not be rejected.

questions.title: Hypothesis Testing
questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding a one-tailed hypothesis test is correct?

choices.A: The rejection region increases in size as the level of significance becomes smaller.
choices.B: A one-tailed test more strongly reflects the beliefs of the researcher than a two-tailed test.
choices.C: The absolute value of the critical value is larger than that for a two-tailed test at the same level of significance.

questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. One-tailed tests in which the alternative is â€œgreater thanâ€ or â€œless thanâ€ represent the beliefs of the researcher more firmly than a â€œnot equal toâ€ alternative hypothesis. A is incorrect because a smaller significance level implies a smaller rejection region. C is incorrect because the absolute value of the critical value for a one-tailed hypothesis test is smaller than that of a two-tailed test. For example, for a two-tailed t-test with 30 degrees of freedom at the 5% significance level, the corresponding critical value is Â±2.042 (2.5% in each tail) whereas the corresponding critical value for a one-tailed t-test is +1.697 or â€“1.697 (5% in the left or right tail). Thus, the absolute value of the critical value is smaller for the one-tailed test than it is for the two-tailed test for the same level of significance.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. One-tailed tests in which the alternative is â€œgreater thanâ€ or â€œless thanâ€ represent the beliefs of the researcher more firmly than a â€œnot equal toâ€ alternative hypothesis.

A is incorrect because a smaller significance level implies a smaller rejection region. C is incorrect because the absolute value of the critical value for a one-tailed hypothesis test is smaller than that of a two-tailed test.

For example, for a two-tailed t-test with 30 degrees of freedom at the 5% significance level, the corresponding critical value is Â±2.042 (2.5% in each tail) whereas the corresponding critical value for a one-tailed t-test is +1.697 or â€“1.697 (5% in the left or right tail). Thus, the absolute value of the critical value is smaller for the one-tailed test than it is for the two-tailed test for the same level of significance.

questions.title: Hypothesis Testing
questions.question:
Given a large random sample, which of the following types of data are least appropriately analyzed with nonparametric tests?

  1. Signed data (e.g., number of positives and negatives)
  2. Ranked data (e.g., 1st, 3rd)
  3. Numerical values (e.g., 28.43, 79.11)
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. Nonparametric tests can be used on grouped or counted data. Incorrect. Nonparametric tests can be used on ranked data. Correct . Nonparametric tests are primarily concerned with ranks, signs, or groups, and they are used when numerical parameters are not known or do not meet assumptions about distributions. Even if the underlying distribution is unknown, parametric tests can be used on numerical data if the sample is large. Hypothesis Testing compare and contrast parametric and nonparametric tests, and describe situations where each is the more appropriate type of test
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect. Nonparametric tests can be used on grouped or counted data.

  2. Incorrect. Nonparametric tests can be used on ranked data.

  3. Correct. Nonparametric tests are primarily concerned with ranks, signs, or groups, and they are used when numerical parameters are not known or do not meet assumptions about distributions. Even if the underlying distribution is unknown, parametric tests can be used on numerical data if the sample is large.

Hypothesis Testing

  • compare and contrast parametric and nonparametric tests, and describe situations where each is the more appropriate type of test

questions.title: Hypothesis Testing
questions.question:
A parametric test is most likely preferred to a non-parametric test when:

  1. the data are given in ratio or ordinal scale.
  2. defined sets of assumptions are given.
  3. the population is heavily skewed.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. A nonparametric test is suitable for this case. Correct . A parametric test is more appropriate than a non-parametric one when an analyst is concerned with parameters whose validity depends on a definite set of assumptionsâ€”for example, assumptions about the distribution of the population producing the sample. Incorrect. A nonparametric test is also suitable for this. Hypothesis Testing compare and contrast parametric and nonparametric tests, and describe situations where each is the more appropriate type of test
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect. A nonparametric test is suitable for this case.

  2. Correct. A parametric test is more appropriate than a non-parametric one when an analyst is concerned with parameters whose validity depends on a definite set of assumptionsâ€”for example, assumptions about the distribution of the population producing the sample.

  3. Incorrect. A nonparametric test is also suitable for this.

Hypothesis Testing

  • compare and contrast parametric and nonparametric tests, and describe situations where each is the more appropriate type of test

questions.title: Hypothesis Testing
questions.question: If a researcher selects a 5 percent level of significance for a hypothesis test, the confidence level is:

choices.B: 5 percent.
choices.C: 95 percent.

questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. The 5 percent level of significance (i.e., probability of a Type I error) corresponds to 1 âˆ’ 0.05 = 0.95, or a 95 percent confidence level (i.e., probability of not rejecting a true null hypothesis). The level of significance is the complement to the confidence level; in other words, they sum to 1.00, or 100 percent.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

C is correct. The 5 percent level of significance (i.e., probability of a Type I error) corresponds to 1 âˆ’ 0.05 = 0.95, or a 95 percent confidence level (i.e., probability of not rejecting a true null hypothesis). The level of significance is the complement to the confidence level; in other words, they sum to 1.00, or 100 percent.

questions.title: Hypothesis Testing
questions.question:
Using the following sample results drawn as 25 paired observations from their underlying distributions, test whether the mean returns of the two portfolios differ from each other at the 1% level of statistical significance. Assume the underlying distributions of returns for each portfolio are normal and that their population variances are not known.

Portfolio 1 Portfolio 2 Difference
Mean return 17.00 21.25 4.25
Standard deviation 15.50 15.75 6.25

t-statistic for 24 degrees of freedom and at the 1% level of statistical significance = 2.807

Null hypothesis (H0): Mean difference of returns = 0

Based on the paired comparisons test of the two portfolios, the most appropriate conclusion is that H0 should be:

  1. rejected because the computed test statistic exceeds 2.807.
  2. accepted because the computed test statistic exceeds 2.807.
  3. accepted because the computed test statistic is less than 2.807.
questions.explanation: Solution Correct because the test statistic is: ğ‘‘ â¯ â¯ âˆ’ ğœ‡ ğ‘‘ 0 ğ‘  ğ‘‘ / ğ‘› âˆš d Â¯ âˆ’ Î¼ d 0 s d / n where ğ‘‘ â¯ â¯ d Â¯ = the mean difference Î¼ d 0 = the hypothesized difference in the means s d = the sample standard deviation of differences n = the sample size In this case, the test statistic equals: ( 4.25 âˆ’ 0 ) ( 6.25 / 25 âˆš ) ( 4.25 âˆ’ 0 ) ( 6.25 / 25 ) = 3.40. Because 3.40 2.807, the null hypothesis that the mean difference is zero is rejected. Incorrect because a too large (or too small) test statistic leads to the rejection of the null hypothesis. Incorrect because the correctly computed test statistic exceeds the critical value of 2.807. Hypothesis Testing construct hypothesis tests and determine their statistical significance, the associated Type I and Type II errors, and power of the test given a significance level
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Correct because the test statistic is: ğ‘‘â¯â¯âˆ’ğœ‡ğ‘‘0ğ‘ ğ‘‘/ğ‘›âˆšdÂ¯âˆ’Î¼d0sd/n where

    ğ‘‘â¯â¯dÂ¯ = the mean difference

    Î¼d0 = the hypothesized difference in the means

    sd = the sample standard deviation of differences

    n = the sample size

    In this case, the test statistic equals: (4.25âˆ’0)(6.25/25âˆš)(4.25âˆ’0)(6.25/25) = 3.40. Because 3.40

    2.807, the null hypothesis that the mean difference is zero is rejected.

  2. Incorrect because a too large (or too small) test statistic leads to the rejection of the null hypothesis.

  3. Incorrect because the correctly computed test statistic exceeds the critical value of 2.807.

Hypothesis Testing

  • construct hypothesis tests and determine their statistical significance, the associated Type I and Type II errors, and power of the test given a significance level

questions.title: Hypothesis Testing
questions.question: A hypothesis test for a normally distributed population, at a 0.05 significance level, implies a:

choices.A: 95 percent probability of rejecting a true null hypothesis.
choices.B: 95 percent probability of a Type I error for a two-tailed test.
choices.C: 5 percent critical value rejection region for a one-tailed test.

questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. For a one-tailed hypothesis test, there is a 5 percent rejection region in one tail of the distribution. A is incorrect because a 5 percent significance level implies a 5 percent probability of rejecting the null hypothesis and a 95 percent confidence interval. B is incorrect because the probability of a Type I error (mistakenly rejecting a true null) is the stated 5 percent significance level.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

C is correct. For a one-tailed hypothesis test, there is a 5 percent rejection region in one tail of the distribution. A is incorrect because a 5 percent significance level implies a 5 percent probability of rejecting the null hypothesis and a 95 percent confidence interval. B is incorrect because the probability of a Type I error (mistakenly rejecting a true null) is the stated 5 percent significance level.

questions.title: Hypothesis Testing
questions.question:
A small-cap growth fundâ€™s monthly returns for the past 36 months have been consistently outperforming its benchmark. An analyst is determining whether the standard deviation of monthly returns is greater than 6%. Which of the following best describes the hypothesis to be tested?

  1. H0: Ïƒ2 â‰¤ 0.36%
  2. Ha: Ïƒ2 6%
  3. H0: Ïƒ2 â‰¥ 0.36%
questions.explanation: Solution Correct because this is a one-tailed hypothesis testing with a â€œgreater thanâ€ alternative hypothesis. A squared standard deviation is being used to obtain a test of variance. The hypotheses are H 0 : Ïƒ 2 â‰¤ 0.36% versus H a : Ïƒ 2 0.36%. Incorrect because this is a one-tailed hypothesis testing with a â€œgreater thanâ€ alternative hypothesis. A squared standard deviation is being used to obtain a test of variance. The hypotheses are H 0 : Ïƒ 2 â‰¤ 0.36% versus H a : Ïƒ 2 0.36%. Incorrect because this is a one-tailed hypothesis testing with a â€œgreater thanâ€ alternative hypothesis. A squared standard deviation is being used to obtain a test of variance. The hypotheses are H 0 : Ïƒ 2 â‰¤ 0.36% versus H a : Ïƒ 2 0.36%. Hypothesis Testing construct hypothesis tests and determine their statistical significance, the associated Type I and Type II errors, and power of the test given a significance level
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Correct because this is a one-tailed hypothesis testing with a â€œgreater thanâ€ alternative hypothesis. A squared standard deviation is being used to obtain a test of variance. The hypotheses are H0: Ïƒ2 â‰¤ 0.36% versus Ha: Ïƒ2 0.36%.

  2. Incorrect because this is a one-tailed hypothesis testing with a â€œgreater thanâ€ alternative hypothesis. A squared standard deviation is being used to obtain a test of variance. The hypotheses are H0: Ïƒ2 â‰¤ 0.36% versus Ha: Ïƒ2 0.36%.

  3. Incorrect because this is a one-tailed hypothesis testing with a â€œgreater thanâ€ alternative hypothesis. A squared standard deviation is being used to obtain a test of variance. The hypotheses are H0: Ïƒ2 â‰¤ 0.36% versus Ha: Ïƒ2 0.36%.

Hypothesis Testing

  • construct hypothesis tests and determine their statistical significance, the associated Type I and Type II errors, and power of the test given a significance level

questions.title: Hypothesis Testing
questions.question: The value of a test statistic is best described as the basis for deciding whether to:

choices.B: accept the null hypothesis.
choices.C: reject the alternative hypothesis.

questions.explanation: Solution A is correct. In hypothesis testing, a test statistic is a quantity whose value is the basis for deciding whether to reject the null hypothesis.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

A is correct. In hypothesis testing, a test statistic is a quantity whose value is the basis for deciding whether to reject the null hypothesis.

questions.title: Hypothesis Testing
questions.question: Which of the following best describes a Type I error?

choices.B: Rejecting a false null hypothesis
choices.C: Failing to reject a false null hypothesis

questions.explanation: Solution A is correct. The definition of a Type I error is when a true null hypothesis is rejected.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

A is correct. The definition of a Type I error is when a true null hypothesis is rejected.

questions.title: Hypothesis Testing
questions.question:
Independent samples drawn from normally distributed populations exhibit the following characteristics:

Sample Size Sample Mean Standard Deviation
A 25 200 45
B 18 185 60

Assuming that the variances of the underlying populations are equal, the pooled estimate of the common variance is 2,678.05. The t-test statistic appropriate to test the hypothesis that the two population means are equal is closest to:

  1. 1.90.
  2. 0.29.
  3. 0.94.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. The mistake is to divide 2678.05 by 43 (25 + 18) and use the square root of the result as the divisor for the t -statistic: (200 âˆ’ 185)/(2678.05/43) 0.5 = 1.90. Incorrect. The mistake is to take an equally weighted average of the given standard deviations and use this as the divisor for the t -statistic: (200 âˆ’ 185)/[(45 + 60)/2] = 0.28571. Correct . The t -statistic for the given information (normally distributed populations, population variances assumed equal) is calculated as: ğ‘¡ = ( ğ‘¥ â¯ â¯ 1 âˆ’ ğ‘¥ â¯ â¯ 2 ) âˆ’ ( ğœ‡ 1 âˆ’ ğœ‡ 2 ) ( ğ‘  2 ğ‘ ğ‘› 1 + ğ‘  2 ğ‘ ğ‘› 2 ) 0.5 t = ( x Â¯ 1 âˆ’ x Â¯ 2 ) âˆ’ ( Î¼ 1 âˆ’ Î¼ 2 ) ( s p 2 n 1 + s p 2 n 2 ) 0.5 In this case we have: ğ‘  2 ğ‘ s p 2 = 2678.05 ğ‘¡ = ( 200 âˆ’ 185 ) âˆ’ ( 0 ) ( 2678.05 25 + 2678.05 18 ) 0.5 t = ( 200 âˆ’ 185 ) âˆ’ ( 0 ) ( 2678.05 25 + 2678.05 18 ) 0.5 = 0.93768 ~ 0.94 Hypothesis Testing construct hypothesis tests and determine their statistical significance, the associated Type I and Type II errors, and power of the test given a significance level
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect. The mistake is to divide 2678.05 by 43 (25 + 18) and use the square root of the result as the divisor for the t-statistic: (200 âˆ’ 185)/(2678.05/43)0.5 = 1.90.

  2. Incorrect. The mistake is to take an equally weighted average of the given standard deviations and use this as the divisor for the t-statistic: (200 âˆ’ 185)/[(45 + 60)/2] = 0.28571.

  3. Correct. The t-statistic for the given information (normally distributed populations, population variances assumed equal) is calculated as:

    ğ‘¡=(ğ‘¥â¯â¯1âˆ’ğ‘¥â¯â¯2)âˆ’(ğœ‡1âˆ’ğœ‡2)(ğ‘ 2ğ‘ğ‘›1+ğ‘ 2ğ‘ğ‘›2)0.5t=(xÂ¯1âˆ’xÂ¯2)âˆ’(Î¼1âˆ’Î¼2)(sp2n1+sp2n2)0.5

    In this case we have:

    ğ‘ 2ğ‘sp2 = 2678.05

    ğ‘¡=(200âˆ’185)âˆ’(0)(2678.0525+2678.0518)0.5t=(200âˆ’185)âˆ’(0)(2678.0525+2678.0518)0.5 = 0.93768 ~ 0.94

Hypothesis Testing

  • construct hypothesis tests and determine their statistical significance, the associated Type I and Type II errors, and power of the test given a significance level

questions.title: Hypothesis Testing
questions.question:
An analyst collects the following data related to paired observations for Sample A and Sample B. Assume that both samples are dependent and are drawn from normally distributed populations and that the population variances are not known.

Paired Observation Sample A Value Sample B Value
1 25 18
2 12 9
3 â€“5 â€“8
4 6 3
5 â€“8 1

The t-statistic to test the hypothesis that the mean difference is equal to zero is closest to:

  1. 0.52.
  2. 0.27.
  3. 0.23.
questions.explanation: Solution Correct . First, the mean difference is calculated: ğ‘‘ â¯ â¯ = 1 ğ‘› âˆ‘ ğ‘– = 1 ğ‘› ğ‘‘ ğ‘– d Â¯ = 1 n âˆ‘ i = 1 n d i Then, the sample variance and the standard error of the mean difference are calculated: ğ‘  2 ğ‘‘ = âˆ‘ ğ‘– = 1 ğ‘› ( ğ‘‘ ğ‘– âˆ’ ğ‘‘ â¯ â¯ ) 2 ğ‘› âˆ’ 1 s d 2 = âˆ‘ i = 1 n ( d i âˆ’ d Â¯ ) 2 n âˆ’ 1 ğ‘  ğ‘‘ â¯ â¯ = ğ‘  ğ‘‘ / ğ‘› âˆš s d Â¯ = s d / n Then, the t -statistic is calculated: ğ‘¡ = ğ‘‘ â¯ â¯ âˆ’ ğœ‡ ğ‘‘ 0 ğ‘  ğ‘‘ â¯ â¯ â¯ t = d Â¯ âˆ’ Î¼ d 0 s d Â¯ In this case, the mean difference is 1.4. The sample variance is 36.8. The standard error of the mean difference is 2.712932. The t -statistic is 0.51605 ~ 0.52 . Paired Observation Sample A Value Sample B Value Differences Differences Minus the Mean Difference, Then Squared 1 25 18 7 (7 âˆ’ 1.4) 2 = 31.36 2 12 9 3 (3 âˆ’ 1.4) 2 = 2.56 3 âˆ’5 âˆ’8 3 (3 âˆ’ 1.4) 2 = 2.56 4 6 3 3 (3 âˆ’ 1.4) 2 = 2.56 5 âˆ’8 1 âˆ’9 (âˆ’9 âˆ’ 1.4) 2 = 108.16 Sum = 7 Sum of squared differences = 147.2 7/5 = mean difference ( ğ‘‘ â¯ â¯ ) ( d Â¯ ) of 1.4 Sample Variance ( ğ‘  2 ğ‘‘ ) ( s d 2 ) : 147.2/4 = 36.8 Standard Error ( ğ‘  ğ‘‘ â¯ â¯ ) ( s d Â¯ ) : (36.8/5) 0.5 = 2.712932 t -statistic: (1.4 âˆ’ 0)/2.712932 = 0.51605 ~ 0.52 Incorrect. The mistake is to calculate the standard deviations of the separate samples and then use the average of these two sample standard deviations as the estimate of s d . Sample A Value Squared Differences 25 (25 âˆ’ 6) 2 = 361 12 (12 âˆ’ 6) 2 = 36 âˆ’5 (âˆ’5 âˆ’ 6) 2 = 121 6 (6 âˆ’ 6) 2 = 0 âˆ’8 (âˆ’8 âˆ’ 6) 2 = 196 Sum = 30 Sum = 714 Mean = 30/5 = 6 Standard deviation = [714/(5 âˆ’ 1)] 0.5 = 13.36039 Sample B Value Squared Differences 18 (18 âˆ’ 4.6) 2 = 179.56 9 (9 âˆ’ 4.6) 2 = 19.36 âˆ’8 (âˆ’8 âˆ’ 4.6) 2 = 158.76 3 (3 âˆ’ 4.6) 2 = 2.56 1 (1 âˆ’ 4.6) 2 = 12.96 Sum = 23 Sum = 373.2 Mean = 23/5 = 4.6 Standard deviation = [373.2/(5 âˆ’ 1)] 0.5 = 9.65919 The average of the two sample standard deviations is: (13.36039 + 9.65919)/2 = 11.50979. Then, the result is found as follows: 1.4 11.50979 / 5 âˆš 1.4 11.50979 / 5 = 0.27. Incorrect. The mistake is to use the sample standard deviation of the differences rather than the standard error of the mean difference in the t -statistic: 1.4 / 36.8 â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ âˆš 1.4 / 36.8 = 0.23. Hypothesis Testing construct hypothesis tests and determine their statistical significance, the associated Type I and Type II errors, and power of the test given a significance level
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Correct. First, the mean difference is calculated:

    ğ‘‘â¯â¯=1ğ‘›âˆ‘ğ‘–=1ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘–dÂ¯=1nâˆ‘i=1ndi

    Then, the sample variance and the standard error of the mean difference are calculated:

    ğ‘ 2ğ‘‘=âˆ‘ğ‘–=1ğ‘›(ğ‘‘ğ‘–âˆ’ğ‘‘â¯â¯)2ğ‘›âˆ’1sd2=âˆ‘i=1n(diâˆ’dÂ¯)2nâˆ’1

    ğ‘ ğ‘‘â¯â¯=ğ‘ ğ‘‘/ğ‘›âˆšsdÂ¯=sd/n

    Then, the t-statistic is calculated:

    ğ‘¡=ğ‘‘â¯â¯âˆ’ğœ‡ğ‘‘0ğ‘ ğ‘‘â¯â¯â¯t=dÂ¯âˆ’Î¼d0sdÂ¯

    In this case, the mean difference is 1.4. The sample variance is 36.8. The standard error of the mean difference is 2.712932. The t-statistic is 0.51605 ~ 0.52.

    Paired Observation Sample A Value Sample B Value Differences Differences Minus the Mean Difference, Then Squared
    1 25 18 7 (7 âˆ’ 1.4)2 = 31.36
    2 12 9 3 (3 âˆ’ 1.4)2 = 2.56
    3 âˆ’5 âˆ’8 3 (3 âˆ’ 1.4)2 = 2.56
    4 6 3 3 (3 âˆ’ 1.4)2 = 2.56
    5 âˆ’8 1 âˆ’9 (âˆ’9 âˆ’ 1.4)2 = 108.16
    Sum = 7 Sum of squared differences = 147.2

    7/5 = mean difference (ğ‘‘â¯â¯)(dÂ¯) of 1.4

    Sample Variance (ğ‘ 2ğ‘‘)(sd2): 147.2/4 = 36.8

    Standard Error (ğ‘ ğ‘‘â¯â¯)(sdÂ¯): (36.8/5)0.5 = 2.712932

    t-statistic: (1.4 âˆ’ 0)/2.712932 = 0.51605 ~ 0.52

  2. Incorrect. The mistake is to calculate the standard deviations of the separate samples and then use the average of these two sample standard deviations as the estimate of sd.

    Sample A Value Squared Differences
    25 (25 âˆ’ 6)2 = 361
    12 (12 âˆ’ 6)2 = 36
    âˆ’5 (âˆ’5 âˆ’ 6)2 = 121
    6 (6 âˆ’ 6)2 = 0
    âˆ’8 (âˆ’8 âˆ’ 6)2 = 196
    Sum = 30 Sum = 714
    Mean = 30/5 = 6 Standard deviation = [714/(5 âˆ’ 1)]0.5
    = 13.36039
    Sample B Value Squared Differences
    18 (18 âˆ’ 4.6)2 = 179.56
    9 (9 âˆ’ 4.6)2 = 19.36
    âˆ’8 (âˆ’8 âˆ’ 4.6)2 = 158.76
    3 (3 âˆ’ 4.6)2 = 2.56
    1 (1 âˆ’ 4.6)2 = 12.96
    Sum = 23 Sum = 373.2
    Mean = 23/5 = 4.6 Standard deviation = [373.2/(5 âˆ’ 1)]0.5
    = 9.65919

    The average of the two sample standard deviations is: (13.36039 + 9.65919)/2 = 11.50979. Then, the result is found as follows: 1.411.50979/5âˆš1.411.50979/5 = 0.27.

  3. Incorrect. The mistake is to use the sample standard deviation of the differences rather than the standard error of the mean difference in the t-statistic: 1.4/36.8â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾âˆš1.4/36.8 = 0.23.

Hypothesis Testing

  • construct hypothesis tests and determine their statistical significance, the associated Type I and Type II errors, and power of the test given a significance level

questions.title: Hypothesis Testing
questions.question: A Type II error is best described as:

choices.B: failing to reject a false null hypothesis.
choices.C: failing to reject a false alternative hypothesis.

questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. A Type II error occurs when a false null hypothesis is not rejected.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. A Type II error occurs when a false null hypothesis is not rejected.

questions.title: Hypothesis Testing
questions.question:
Samples of size (n1,n2) are drawn respectively from two populations (X1,X2) with associated sample means and standard deviations of (ğ‘‹â¯â¯â¯1,ğ‘‹â¯â¯â¯2)(XÂ¯1,XÂ¯2) and (s1,s2) and associated population means and standard deviations of (Î¼1,Î¼2) and (Ïƒ1,Ïƒ2) where Ïƒ1 â‰  Ïƒ2. In addition, ğ‘‘â¯â¯dÂ¯ is the sample mean of X1 âˆ’ X2 with a standard error of ğ‘ ğ‘‘â¯â¯sdÂ¯ and a population mean of Î¼d0 and ğ‘ 2ğ‘sp2 is a pooled estimator of the common variance.

The most appropriate test statistic to determine the equality of the two population means assuming X1 and X2 are independent and normally distributed is:

  1. ğ‘¡=ğ‘‘â¯â¯âˆ’ğœ‡ğ‘‘0ğ‘ ğ‘‘â¯â¯â¯t=dÂ¯âˆ’Î¼d0sdÂ¯
  2. ğ‘¡=(ğ‘‹â¯â¯â¯â¯1âˆ’ğ‘‹â¯â¯â¯â¯2)âˆ’(ğœ‡1âˆ’ğœ‡2)(ğ‘ 2ğ‘ğ‘›1+ğ‘ 2ğ‘ğ‘›2)0.5t=(XÂ¯1âˆ’XÂ¯2)âˆ’(Î¼1âˆ’Î¼2)(sp2n1+sp2n2)0.5
  3. ğ‘¡=(ğ‘‹â¯â¯â¯â¯1âˆ’ğ‘‹â¯â¯â¯â¯2)âˆ’(ğœ‡1âˆ’ğœ‡2)(ğ‘ 21ğ‘›1+ğ‘ 22ğ‘›2)0.5t=(XÂ¯1âˆ’XÂ¯2)âˆ’(Î¼1âˆ’Î¼2)(s12n1+s22n2)0.5
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. This is the t -test for testing the mean differences (paired comparisons test) with unknown population variances. Incorrect. This is the t -test for testing the difference between two population means (population unknown but assumed equal) where ğ‘  2 ğ‘ s p 2 is a pooled estimator of the common variance. Correct . The most appropriate test statistic for the difference between two population means (unequal and unknown population variances) is ğ‘¡ = ( ğ‘‹ â¯ â¯ â¯ â¯ 1 âˆ’ ğ‘‹ â¯ â¯ â¯ â¯ 2 ) âˆ’ ( ğœ‡ 1 âˆ’ ğœ‡ 2 ) ( ğ‘  2 1 ğ‘› 1 + ğ‘  2 2 ğ‘› 2 ) 0.5 t = ( X Â¯ 1 âˆ’ X Â¯ 2 ) âˆ’ ( Î¼ 1 âˆ’ Î¼ 2 ) ( s 1 2 n 1 + s 2 2 n 2 ) 0.5 Hypothesis Testing construct hypothesis tests and determine their statistical significance, the associated Type I and Type II errors, and power of the test given a significance level
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect. This is the t-test for testing the mean differences (paired comparisons test) with unknown population variances.

  2. Incorrect. This is the t-test for testing the difference between two population means (population unknown but assumed equal) where ğ‘ 2ğ‘sp2 is a pooled estimator of the common variance.

  3. Correct. The most appropriate test statistic for the difference between two population means (unequal and unknown population variances) is

    ğ‘¡=(ğ‘‹â¯â¯â¯â¯1âˆ’ğ‘‹â¯â¯â¯â¯2)âˆ’(ğœ‡1âˆ’ğœ‡2)(ğ‘ 21ğ‘›1+ğ‘ 22ğ‘›2)0.5t=(XÂ¯1âˆ’XÂ¯2)âˆ’(Î¼1âˆ’Î¼2)(s12n1+s22n2)0.5

Hypothesis Testing

  • construct hypothesis tests and determine their statistical significance, the associated Type I and Type II errors, and power of the test given a significance level

questions.title: Hypothesis Testing
questions.question: The level of significance of a hypothesis test is best used to:

choices.B: define the testâ€™s rejection points.
choices.C: specify the probability of a Type II error.

questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. The level of significance is used to establish the rejection points of the hypothesis test. A is correct because the significance level is not used to calculate the test statistic; rather, it is used to determine the critical value. C is incorrect because the significance level specifies the probability of making a Type I error.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. The level of significance is used to establish the rejection points of the hypothesis test. A is correct because the significance level is not used to calculate the test statistic; rather, it is used to determine the critical value. C is incorrect because the significance level specifies the probability of making a Type I error.

questions.title: Hypothesis Testing
questions.question: The probability of correctly rejecting the null hypothesis is the:

choices.B: power of a test.
choices.C: level of significance.

questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. The power of a test is the probability of rejecting the null hypothesis when it is false. A is incorrect because the p-value is the smallest level of significance at which the null hypothesis can be rejected. C is incorrect because the level of significance is the probability of mistakenly rejecting the null hypothesis (Type I error).
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. The power of a test is the probability of rejecting the null hypothesis when it is false. A is incorrect because the p-value is the smallest level of significance at which the null hypothesis can be rejected. C is incorrect because the level of significance is the probability of mistakenly rejecting the null hypothesis (Type I error).

questions.title: Hypothesis Testing
questions.question:
During the past 36 months, the standard deviation of a portfolioâ€™s monthly returns has been 4.9%. To test a claim that this portfolioâ€™s investment strategy results in a standard deviation of monthly returns that is less than 5.0%, the value of the test statistic is closest to:

  1. 34.30.
  2. 33.61.
  3. 34.57.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. If there is no squared to both s and Ïƒ. ( 36 âˆ’ 1 ) ( 0.049 ) ( 0.05 ) = 34.30 ( 36 âˆ’ 1 ) ( 0.049 ) ( 0.05 ) = 34.30 Correct . The most appropriate test is chi-square, with 36 âˆ’ 1 = 35 degrees of freedom. The calculated test statistic is: ğœ’ 2 = ( ğ‘› âˆ’ 1 ) ğ‘  2 ğœ 2 0 = ( 36 âˆ’ 1 ) ( 0.049 ) 2 ( 0.05 ) 2 = 33.61 Ï‡ 2 = ( n âˆ’ 1 ) s 2 Ïƒ 0 2 = ( 36 âˆ’ 1 ) ( 0.049 ) 2 ( 0.05 ) 2 = 33.61 where Ï‡ 2 = is the chi-square test statistic n = is the sample size s 2 = is the sample variance ğœ 2 0 Ïƒ 0 2 = the hypothesized value of the variance Ïƒ 2 Incorrect. If using n as degrees of freedom instead of n âˆ’ 1, that is ( 36 ) ( 0.049 ) 2 ( 0.05 ) 2 = 34.57 ( 36 ) ( 0.049 ) 2 ( 0.05 ) 2 = 34.57 Hypothesis Testing construct hypothesis tests and determine their statistical significance, the associated Type I and Type II errors, and power of the test given a significance level
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect. If there is no squared to both s and Ïƒ.

    (36âˆ’1)(0.049)(0.05)=34.30(36âˆ’1)(0.049)(0.05)=34.30

  2. Correct. The most appropriate test is chi-square, with 36 âˆ’ 1 = 35 degrees of freedom. The calculated test statistic is: ğœ’2=(ğ‘›âˆ’1)ğ‘ 2ğœ20=(36âˆ’1)(0.049)2(0.05)2=33.61Ï‡2=(nâˆ’1)s2Ïƒ02=(36âˆ’1)(0.049)2(0.05)2=33.61
    where

    Ï‡2 = is the chi-square test statistic

    n = is the sample size

    s2 = is the sample variance

    ğœ20Ïƒ02 = the hypothesized value of the variance Ïƒ2

  3. Incorrect. If using n as degrees of freedom instead of n âˆ’ 1, that is

    (36)(0.049)2(0.05)2=34.57(36)(0.049)2(0.05)2=34.57

Hypothesis Testing

  • construct hypothesis tests and determine their statistical significance, the associated Type I and Type II errors, and power of the test given a significance level

questions.title: Hypothesis Testing
questions.question: The power of a hypothesis test is:

choices.A: equivalent to the level of significance.
choices.B: the probability of not making a Type II error.
choices.C: unchanged by increasing a small sample size.

questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. The power of a hypothesis test is the probability of correctly rejecting the null when it is false. Failing to reject the null when it is false is a Type II error. Thus, the power of a hypothesis test is the probability of not committing a Type II error.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. The power of a hypothesis test is the probability of correctly rejecting the null when it is false. Failing to reject the null when it is false is a Type II error. Thus, the power of a hypothesis test is the probability of not committing a Type II error.

questions.title: Hypothesis Testing
questions.question:
An analyst examines 30 paired monthly returns for two stock indexes. To determine if the mean difference of the returns is zero, the number of degrees of freedom of the t-test is:

  1. 28.
  2. 29.
  3. 58.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because the t -statistic for a paired comparisons test has n â€“ 1 degrees of freedom, not n â€“ 2 degrees of freedom, where n is the number of pairs of observations. When n = 30, the number of degrees of freedom is 30 â€“ 1 = 29, not 30 â€“ 2 = 28. Correct because the t -statistic for a paired comparisons test has n â€“ 1 degrees of freedom, where n is the number of pairs of observations. When n = 30, the number of degrees of freedom is 30 â€“ 1 = 29. Incorrect because this is the number of degrees of freedom of the t -statistic for a hypothesis test concerning the equality of the population means of two independent samples, which is n 1 + n 2 âˆ’ 2. When both n 1 and n 2 is 30, the number of degrees of freedom of the t -statistic for a hypothesis test concerning the equality of the population means of two independent samples is 30 + 30 âˆ’ 2 = 58. Hypothesis Testing construct hypothesis tests and determine their statistical significance, the associated Type I and Type II errors, and power of the test given a significance level
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect because the t-statistic for a paired comparisons test has n â€“ 1 degrees of freedom, not n â€“ 2 degrees of freedom, where n is the number of pairs of observations. When n = 30, the number of degrees of freedom is 30 â€“ 1 = 29, not 30 â€“ 2 = 28.

  2. Correct because the t-statistic for a paired comparisons test has n â€“ 1 degrees of freedom, where n is the number of pairs of observations. When n = 30, the number of degrees of freedom is 30 â€“ 1 = 29.

  3. Incorrect because this is the number of degrees of freedom of the t-statistic for a hypothesis test concerning the equality of the population means of two independent samples, which is n1 + n2 âˆ’ 2. When both n1 and n2 is 30, the number of degrees of freedom of the t-statistic for a hypothesis test concerning the equality of the population means of two independent samples is 30 + 30 âˆ’ 2 = 58.

Hypothesis Testing

  • construct hypothesis tests and determine their statistical significance, the associated Type I and Type II errors, and power of the test given a significance level

questions.title: Hypothesis Testing
questions.question: In the step â€œstating a decision ruleâ€ in testing a hypothesis, which of the following elements must be specified?

choices.B: Power of a test
choices.C: Value of a test statistic

questions.explanation: Solution A is correct. The critical value in a decision rule is the rejection point for the test. It is the point with which the test statistic is compared to determine whether to reject the null hypothesis, which is part of the fourth step in hypothesis testing. B is incorrect because the power of a test refers to the probability of rejecting the null hypothesis when it is false. C is incorrect because the value of the test statistic is specified in the â€˜Identify the appropriate test statistic and its probability distributionâ€ step.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

A is correct. The critical value in a decision rule is the rejection point for the test. It is the point with which the test statistic is compared to determine whether to reject the null hypothesis, which is part of the fourth step in hypothesis testing. B is incorrect because the power of a test refers to the probability of rejecting the null hypothesis when it is false. C is incorrect because the value of the test statistic is specified in the â€˜Identify the appropriate test statistic and its probability distributionâ€ step.

questions.title: Hypothesis Testing
questions.question: A pooled estimator is used when testing a hypothesis concerning the:

choices.A: equality of the variances of two normally distributed populations.
choices.B: difference between the means of two approximately normally distributed populations with unknown but assumed equal variances.
choices.C: difference between the means of two at least approximately normally distributed populations with unknown and assumed unequal variances.

questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. The assumption that the variances are equal allows for the combining of both samples to obtain a pooled estimate of the common variance.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. The assumption that the variances are equal allows for the combining of both samples to obtain a pooled estimate of the common variance.

questions.title: Hypothesis Testing
questions.question: When evaluating mean differences between two dependent samples, the most appropriate test is a:

choices.B: chi-square test.
choices.C: paired comparisons test.

questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. A paired comparisons test is appropriate to test the mean differences of two samples believed to be dependent. A is incorrect because a z-test is used to determine whether two population means are different when the variances are known and the sample size is large. B is incorrect because a chi-square test is used for tests concerning the variance of a single normally distributed population.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

C is correct. A paired comparisons test is appropriate to test the mean differences of two samples believed to be dependent. A is incorrect because a z-test is used to determine whether two population means are different when the variances are known and the sample size is large. B is incorrect because a chi-square test is used for tests concerning the variance of a single normally distributed population.

questions.title: Hypothesis Testing
questions.question: A chi-square test is most appropriate for tests concerning:

choices.B: differences between two population means with variances assumed to be equal.
choices.C: differences between two population means with variances not assumed to be equal.

questions.explanation: Solution A is correct. A chi-square test is used for tests concerning the variance of a single normally distributed population.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

A is correct. A chi-square test is used for tests concerning the variance of a single normally distributed population.

questions.title: Hypothesis Testing
questions.question: Which of the following tests should be used to test the difference between the variances of two normally distributed populations with random independent samples?

choices.B: F -test
choices.C: Paired comparisons test

questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. An F -test is used to conduct tests concerning the difference between the variances of two normally distributed populations with random independent samples.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. An F-test is used to conduct tests concerning the difference between the variances of two normally distributed populations with random independent samples.

questions.title: Hypothesis Testing
questions.question: A nonparametric test is most appropriate when the:

choices.B: validity of the test depends on many assumptions.
choices.C: sample sizes are large but are drawn from a population that may be non-normal.

questions.explanation: Solution A is correct. When the samples consist of ranked values, parametric tests are not appropriate. In such cases, nonparametric tests are most appropriate.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

A is correct. When the samples consist of ranked values, parametric tests are not appropriate. In such cases, nonparametric tests are most appropriate.

questions.title: Hypothesis Testing
questions.question: In which of the following situations would a nonparametric test of a hypothesis most likely be used?

choices.A: The sample data are ranked according to magnitude.
choices.B: The sample data come from a normally distributed population.
choices.C: The test validity depends on many assumptions about the nature of the population.

questions.explanation: Solution A is correct. A nonparametric test is used when the data are given in ranks.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

A is correct. A nonparametric test is used when the data are given in ranks.

questions.title: Hypothesis Testing
questions.question: An analyst is examining the monthly returns for two funds over one year. Both fundsâ€™ returns are non-normally distributed. To test whether the mean return of one fund is greater than the mean return of the other fund, the analyst can use:

choices.B: a nonparametric test only.
choices.C: both parametric and nonparametric tests.

questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. There are only 12 (monthly) observations over the one year of the sample and thus the samples are small. Additionally, the fundsâ€™ returns are non-normally distributed. Therefore, the samples do not meet the distributional assumptions for a parametric test. The Mannâ€“Whitney U test (a nonparametric test) could be used to test the differences between population means.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. There are only 12 (monthly) observations over the one year of the sample and thus the samples are small. Additionally, the fundsâ€™ returns are non-normally distributed. Therefore, the samples do not meet the distributional assumptions for a parametric test. The Mannâ€“Whitney U test (a nonparametric test) could be used to test the differences between population means.
